dek: We looked at 19 years of covers to find how Vogue represents women of all shades

intro.value: In 2014, Lupita Nyongo’o, a Mexican-Kenyan actress and model, revealed that she used to pray for lighter skin. For most of her childhood, she saw her complexion as “an obstacle to overcome.”

She addressed a facet of racism called colorism. It’s the idea that, for people of color, lighter skin is more desirable. In the same way that white women will have an easier time than women of color, light-skinned women of color will have an easier time than dark-skinned women of color. Another way of looking at it is, even though racial and ethnic diversity in fashion and the media is improving, dark-skinned women still aren’t getting the representation they deserve.

To investigate this, we looked at the covers of Vogue magazine, a bastion of fashion that has been reporting on and setting trends for over a century. For models, being on the cover of Vogue magazine is a big deal. As Beverly Johnson, Vogue’s first black cover model puts it, “This is our Oscar. This is our gold medal. This is everything in the industry.”

Others have analyzed the racial and ethnic makeup of Vogue’s cover models, but we’re more interested in looking at their diversity through the lens of colorism. Vogue may be hiring women of all races, but are they representing women of all shades?

lupita.value: We looked at every cover of Vogue for the last nineteen years, and measured how light the cover models were. Five of the six darkest cover models appeared in the last five years, and four of these six models were Lupita. She is one of the only women with a dark skin tone to appear on the cover, and she is the only dark-skinned professional model to appear on the cover of Vogue in the last nineteen years. (Other women with similar skin tones that appeared include ex-first lady Michelle Obama, and Olympian Serena Williams.)

calculationIntro.value: To analyze the last nineteen years of Vogue covers, we gave each cover model a number that represents how light her skin looks in the photograph.

Cover photos are heavily edited in all sorts of ways. There are cosmetic fixes, like slimming the model, or airbrushing any “unsightly” hairs. But there are also artistic edits, like changing the saturation of a photo, or deepening shadows. It’s unclear where adjusting the lighting fits in. Regardless of the intention, it often results in women of color appearing more light.
The lightness values that we’ve calculated for a model refers to how she was portrayed on the cover: how the editors of Vogue chose to display her.
Here’s how we get that number:

tonesIntro.value: In the past nineteen years, there have been 228 issues of Vogue, with a total of 262 female cover models. Let’s look at where these women fall on the lightness spectrum.

beeswarmStep1.value: Vogue cover models are generally lighter, with a few outliers.

beeswarmStep2.value: On the darker end of the spectrum are actress Lupita Nyongo, tennis star Serena Williams, and former first lady Michelle Obama.

beeswarmStep3.value: On the lighter end you can find actresses Jessica Chastain and Anne Hathaway and singer Lady Gaga.

beeswarmStep4.value: This data is flattened, but we can look at another dimension of this data: time.

beeswarmStep5.value: Between 2000 and 2005, there isn’t a lot of variance in how light the cover models appear. In the next ten years, there’s a bit more spread. And in the last four years, the variance increases again. So what’s going on?

beeswarmStep6.value: Certainly, part of it is due to the race of the models that appeared on the cover. Between 2000 and 2005, only three of eighty-one cover models were black, and all of these women had lighter skin.

beeswarmStep7.value: Part of it, however, can be attributed to the style of photography that appears on the cover of Vogue. Compared to the early 2000s, the more recent covers are more artistic, with rich, lush colors, and dramatic lighting. This accounts for some of the spread as well.

beeswarmStep8.value: And part of it is Lupita Nyongo’o. With her four recent appearances, she is single handedly tugging the trend towards the left.
